title: Mathematical Modeling-Based Instructional Design for Classroom Behavior Management Performance Support Systems: Application of Matrix Operations and Optimization Techniques

context.prior_knowledge: Basic classroom management concepts, experience with mobile learning tools, understanding of matrix operations (multiplication, transpose, inverse matrices), graph theory (node/edge concepts), and probabilistic modeling
context.additional_context: Instructional design training to strengthen classroom behavior management strategies within the mathematics curriculum. Emphasizes behavior pattern analysis using data visualization (heatmaps, network graphs), probabilistic modeling (Markov chains), and optimization techniques (linear programming). Integrates mathematical proofs and computational thinking throughout the curriculum.

learning_goals: Learners can design logical interconnections between modules of a classroom behavior management system by applying advance organizer theory and mathematical modeling (graph theory and matrix operations).
Learners can visually represent the information structure of a PSS (Performance Support System) using matrix design metaphors and matrix operations (multiplication, transposition, inverse matrices).

Learners can collaborate with two peer teachers and three parents within a week to develop one optimization algorithm (probabilistic modeling or linear programming) for classroom behavior management during project-based assessments and submit an execution report meeting at least 4/5 rubric criteria.
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
